title: Stop the 'Two-Hand Push'
author: adam-harrington
description: The most common youth shooting error: pushing the ball with both hands like a chest pass. This drill sequence teaches proper one-hand dominance for a mechanically sound jumper.
coachNote: Adam's Take: Every kid starts by pushing the ball with two hands. It's natural—they're not strong enough yet. But if we don't fix it by age 10, it becomes permanent. The guide hand should be a 'ghost'—there but not pushing.

steps.title: Guide Hand Awareness
steps.instruction: Place your guide hand on the side of the ball with fingers pointing UP (not forward). This hand does NOT push—it only balances. Practice holding this position without shooting.

steps.title: Guide Hand Release
steps.instruction: Shoot from 5 feet. The MOMENT before release, your guide hand should fall away. It literally 'lets go' before the shooting hand finishes. Watch for the guide hand thumb—it should NOT be pointing at the basket.

steps.title: One-Hand Only
steps.instruction: Shoot 10 shots with your guide hand behind your back. This forces your shooting arm to do all the work. Start at 3-4 feet from the basket—this is about form, not distance.

steps.title: Thumb Check
steps.instruction: After each shot, freeze and look at your guide hand thumb. Is it pointing at the basket? That means it pushed. It should be pointing UP or sideways, not forward.

steps.title: Gradual Distance
steps.instruction: Once form is clean at 5 feet, move to 8 feet, then 10. Never sacrifice form for distance. If the two-hand push returns, move back in.

coachingCues: Guide hand thumb should NEVER point at the basket after release
Think of the guide hand as a 'kickstand'—it balances, it doesn't power
Start CLOSE to the basket—distance is earned with form
If you need two hands to reach the basket, you're too far away
commonMistake: Shooting from too far away before mastering form
mistakeFix: Move in until you can make shots with ONE hand. That's your training distance.
